moves.1. d4: Black started to pursuit my pieces from the beginning of the game until almost his last move in a strategy more suited to blitz games... his efforts were aimless and pointless and were all tamed, while I profited to develop an attack on his exposed king... he latter timed out
moves.1... Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 d5 4. cxd5 Nxd5: I played this position on several games...
moves.7. Rc1: ...I never, though, played this move, let's see what does it brings, the idea is to hit c7 early on
moves.7... Nb6 8. Bg5 h6 9. Bf4 g5: over extending the pawn in front of his king might get it exposed latter on
moves.10. Be5 f6: black's king side pawn structure looks miserable, the light squares resemble a sieve... and c7 is also vulnerable, let's try to profit from it.
moves.11. Qb3+: letting the bishop hanging to bring my queen out
moves.11... Kh8 12. Bg3: and only now remove the threatened bishop
moves.13. Be5: the bishop is back on the best placement and now can't be expelled by pawns
moves.13... Nb8d7 14. Bxg7+: to increase black's weakness on the king side
moves.15. e3: securing d4 and opening the bishop exit
moves.16. Nd2 e5 17. Ne2 f4: black achieves nothing by this line of play... maybe on a blitz game it would do some damage, but with his pieces remaining on their home squares he can't do any decent attack effort as we will surely see latter
moves.18. exf4 exf4 19. h3: challenging the advanced pawns and threatening to bring my rook on to the game
moves.19... Re8: again hitting on one of my pieces but lacking to coordinate his efforts
moves.21... h5: the g pawn is pinned so I don't have g5
moves.22. Qf3: shifting my pressure on to f4
moves.22... c6: ? what is the point of this?
moves.23. Qxf4 Nfd5: and black likes to pursuit my pieces all over the board without any concrete objective
moves.24. Qg3 hxg4 25. Nf3: profiting from the pinned pawn to develop my knight
moves.26. Qh2: threatening to finally infiltrate black's king side
